speaker: Frasier
text: [_on-air_] Hello, Rachel.  I'm listening.

speaker: Rachel
text: [_v.o._] Oh, thanks for taking my call, Dr. Crane.  Um, I'm involved in sort of a strange love triangle.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_off-air, to Roz_] Oh goody, this is sweeps week! [_on-air_]

speaker: Rachel
text: You see, I recently married a widower.  Now, Phil's a real good man, he's a kind man.  But there's just one little problem.  He insists on keeping an urn with his late wife's ashes on the dresser in our bedroom.

speaker: Frasier
text: That is a definite "Yikes."

speaker: Rachel
text: See, I knew that wasn't normal.  He says it is, but I knew it wasn't!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, Rachel, Rachel, now listen.  Before you go off half-cocked, let's try to remember this is a very sensitive issue for your husband.  Obviously those ashes mean a very great deal to him.  And although I don't believe it's appropriate that he keep them in the bedroom, I suppose you could maybe move them to another room?

speaker: Rachel
text: Well, I guess I could try that.  Maybe I'll move them into the guest room. [_sound of crockery breaking_] Oops.

speaker: Frasier
text: Rachel, what happened?

speaker: Rachel
text: Oh... oh, nothing.  I gotta run, Dr. Crane.  I've got some vacuuming to do.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, as Rachel helps Phil's wife off the floor, we have reached the end of our second hour.  Now, we'll be right back after the news, so please join me again, Frasier Crane and my invaluable producer... ah... [_ohmygod, what's her name?  It's, it's..._]

speaker: Roz
text: ROZ!

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz!  KACL Talk radio, 780 AM.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, I'm so sorry.  Your name was right there in front of me and I just couldn't put my finger on it.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, forget about it.  I already have.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's been happening to me a lot lately.  Last night I walked into the kitchen and I just stood there.  I couldn't remember what I'd gone in there for.

speaker: Roz
text: Don't make yourself crazy over it, it's completely normal. Oh, by the way, you hair stylist called to confirm your appointment.

speaker: Frasier
text: I made an appointment with Timo?  I don't remember that.

speaker: Roz
text: That's 'cause you didn't, I was just gas-lighting you.

speaker: Frasier
text: That is not funny!

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, lighten up.  Here, sign these. [_hand him some forms_] So aren't you gonna say it, or are you going to make me wait 'til the end of the day?

speaker: Frasier
text: Say what?

speaker: Roz
text: Happy birthday.

speaker: Frasier
text: It is not your birthday. [_sees her stricken face_] Oh, God. Oh God, it is.  Oh, oh Roz, I'm so sorry!  Let me take you out to lunch after work, okay?

speaker: Roz
text: [_laughing_] You are so easy!

speaker: Frasier
text: That's it.  I'm outta here! [_exits into corridor_]

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, wait, wait, wait.  Aren't you forgetting something?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I am not forgetting anything, thank you, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Okay.  Well, can't blame a girl for trying.  Five, four, three...

speaker: Roz
text: Two...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_on air_] We're back. **THE SHORT BLONDE MAN WITH ONE WET SHOE**  _Scene Two: Frasier's apartment. Martin and Niles are playing Canasta.  Eddie is worrying Niles's shoe._

speaker: Niles
text: Ten.

speaker: Martin
text: Fifteen-two.

speaker: Niles
text: No! [_then_] Dad, would you ask your dog to stop burrowing at my shoes?  I'll have you know I had to wait six months to have these shipped for a little blind cobbler in Seville.

speaker: Martin
text: He won't stop until you scratch him behind the ear.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, all right Eddie, all right.  _He wraps a finger in his handkerchief and scratches Eddie's ear. Eddie runs off, contented._

speaker: Niles
text: You know, I'm beginning to this I have an affinity towards animals.

speaker: Frasier
text: Would either of you mind if I noodled at the piano for a bit?

speaker: Niles
text: Would it really stop you if we said "Yes?"

speaker: Frasier
text: Point well taken. _He sits at the piano and starts to play, but loses the tune at around the sixth bar._

speaker: Frasier
text: That's strange.  For the life of me, I can't remember what the next note is. [_tries again, but stumbles at the same point_] I know this piece backwards and forwards.

speaker: Niles
text: Perhaps if you start at the end you'll have better luck.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, come on Frasier.  You know how it goes.  It goes, "da dada da da, da dada..."

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, thank you dad.  Now it's perfectly clear. [_tries once more, then gives up in disgust_]

speaker: Martin
text: That was very nice, son.  Now how about something from "South Pacific?"

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry.  Just getting fed up with this nonsense.  I'm forgetting names all the time.  You know, last week, twice I forgot where I parked my car.

speaker: Martin
text: Join the club, pal.  You're getting older.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well of course I'm getting older.  We're all getting older.  But I'm not that old.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I'm afraid dad may have a point.  I know you'd like to believe we're still the same devilish sprigs we always were. Sitting on mother's davenport in our tweeds and tans, listening to the Texaco symphonic hour.  The cold-hearted reality is, you're middle-aged.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I'm forty-one.  That's hardly middle-aged.  Middle age is more like fifty, fifty-five.

speaker: Niles
text: Only if you live to be one hundred and ten.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm all ready to go, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, where are you two off to?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm giving Daphne a lift.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm meeting some of my girlfriends for darts and a couple of pints.  Oh, it's best to do it in that order.  Just ask Blind Willie, the bartender.

speaker: Frasier
text: Listen Daphne, before you go, I'd like to ask you a little question here.  When you look at me, um, do you see me as a young man, or as an older man?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, no.  No, you don't.  You're not getting me into that Vietnam.  I learned a long time ago there are three questions you never answer honestly.  "How old do I look?"  "Do you like my hair?" and "Was it good for you too?" [_to Niles_] Coming, Dr. Crane? ...Dr. Crane?

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry, I was someplace else. [_to Frasier_] It was a warm and friendly place.

speaker: Frasier
text: Big surprise, I got a headache.  Let me get an aspirin.  The very suggestion that I'm descending into old age just because I can't remember a couple of names, or a tune on the piano.  _He takes a medicine bottle out of the cupboard, but has trouble reading the label._

speaker: Martin
text: Your arm's not quite long enough for that, is it?  Let me ask you a few questions.  Can you get through the night without getting up to go to the john?  Can you get in and out of a chair without going "Mmmm?"  Can you eat a slice of pizza less than twelve hours before you go to bed?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_after a beat_] What's on the pizza?

speaker: Martin
text: A-ha.  I thought so.  Alright, well now we've established you're middle-aged.  Take some advice: don't fight it, it'll go a lot easier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good lord, dad, what are you suggesting?  I'm gonna rush off to a plastic surgeon to get an eye lift and a chin tuck? [_examines his face in a silver plate_] Oh, dear god!

speaker: Martin
text: [_looking in family album_] I'm just telling you, when guys get to this stage they do some squirrelly things that they never would have done when they were younger.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, please spare me, I am a psychiatrist, I know the routine. [_notices the photograph Martin is pointing to_] Good lord, who is that?

speaker: Martin
text: That's me.  In '74.  Going through my own little stage.  I'd dyed my hair jet black and bought a leather jacket and a Harley Davidson.

speaker: Frasier
text: My God, dad.  You look like one of the Village People.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, fortunately I came to my senses before you got back from Harvard that summer.

speaker: Frasier
text: Are those love beads?

speaker: Martin
text: All right, that's enough.  Just do me a favour, will ya?  Keep your guard up, and don't do something stupid, all right?

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, dad.

speaker: Martin
text: You may think it's tough being middle-aged, but think about me.  I got a son who's middle-aged.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ahhhh...

speaker: Martin
text: [_o.s._] I heard that!  _End Of Act One.  Act Two._  **IT'S THIS OR AN ALFA ROMEO**  _Scene One: Department store, gents casual. Frasier and Martin enter._

speaker: Martin
text: Say, didn't this used to be Pinski's department store?

speaker: Frasier
text: I have no idea.

speaker: Martin
text: Sure it was.  we used to bring you kids here all the time. Man, it was a great store.  You could buy lingerie, a bag of popcorn and transmission fluid, all under the same roof.

speaker: Frasier
text: Finally, something I'm glad I forgot.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, Mr. Crane, I believe I came here on a mission.

speaker: Martin
text: Alright, but remember, I don't want anything fancy or that comes in tubes.  I want them white, I want them plain, and I want them boxers.

speaker: Daphne
text: That's the exactly the kind of lack of imagination that sunk the British Empire.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Frasier.  Check out these dress pants.  They got elastic panels in the waist.  You could eat all you want, and never worry about cutting off your circulation.

speaker: Frasier
text: Milan must be beside itself.  What an innovative use of synthetic fibres.  I believe if you recycle these, you can turn them into milk containers.

speaker: Martin
text: Are you gonna get them or not?

speaker: Frasier
text: You brought these over for me?!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, the sands of time are shifting, buddy - mostly south! Listen, if you don't want to go with elastic, maybe you could go with suspenders.  That way, if you keep your jacket closed, that little gut of yours can hang down to here and nobody's any the wiser.

speaker: Frasier
text: I do not have a gut! [_looks at himself sideways in the mirror_] I have... contours.

speaker: Carrie
text: Excuse me. I was wondering if anyone was helping you?

speaker: Martin
text: [_seeing Daphne_] Oh, no.  She's looking at something with stripes! [_goes over_] Daphne!  Daphne, get away from there!

speaker: Carrie
text: [_to Frasier, indicating elastic pants_] You're not thinking of getting those, are you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no.

speaker: Carrie
text: I have something much better over here. [_gets another pair_] What do you think of these?  They don't do much on the hanger but, they could really work on a nice, tall guy like you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, you really think so?

speaker: Carrie
text: Yeah.  You've got a great build.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well.  Thank you very much, ah...?

speaker: Carrie
text: Carrie.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, Carrie.

speaker: Carrie
text: Let's see what we can get working here.  Um, [_picks up sweater_] This is kind of a young look, but you could really pull it off.

speaker: Frasier
text: ...I don't really think it's me.

speaker: Carrie
text: Are you sure?  I think this would look really good on you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I suppose I could try it on.  But you know, just out of curiosity, how old do you think I am?

speaker: Carrie
text: Oh, I don't want to do that.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, no, please go ahead.

speaker: Carrie
text: I don't know.  Um... thirty-six?

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you serious?

speaker: Carrie
text: Oh, God.  I'm sorry.  You're probably more like thirty-four. Now you don't want to buy anything from me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Are those Armani shirts expensive?

speaker: Carrie
text: Yeah.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll take two!

speaker: Carrie
text: Great!  Changing room's right this way.  You know, I love to guess what my customers do by what they wear.  Let me guess. You're an architect, right?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I'm a psychiatrist.

speaker: Carrie
text: Oh.  I've taken some psychiatry courses.  What are you, Freudian?  Reichian?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well actually, lately I've been leaning more towards Jung. Guess that's because I'm "Jung at heart."   [_N.B. This episode was apparently written before the establishment of the Freud/Jung rivalry between Frasier and Niles._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Gotta be the oldest joke in the psychiatrist's joke book. Can't believe I said it. [_goes into changing booth_]

speaker: Carrie
text: I can't believe I laughed at that.

speaker: Frasier
text: I bet you laugh at all of your customer's jokes.

speaker: Carrie
text: No.  Just the cute ones.

speaker: Frasier
text: ...Cute jokes or customers?

speaker: Carrie
text: You figure it out. [_leaves_]  _Time lapse.  Carrie points Martin to Frasier's changing booth.  He goes over._

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, you about ready?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, just a second, dad, I'm trying on a pair of pants.  Hey, did you notice that girl who came over and asked to help us earlier?

speaker: Martin
text: Sure I noticed her.  I'm not dead.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well you know, we just had a little conversation a minute ago and uh, I could swear she was flirting with me.

speaker: Martin
text: [_taking a good look at Carrie_] Trust me son, she's on commission.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh no, I know a sales pitch when I hear one, and that was no sales pitch.  She's definitely interested in me.  Think I may have to see where this may lead.

speaker: Martin
text: I know you're forgetting things lately, but don't you remember the little talk we had last night?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_realizing_] Oh, dear.  It sneaks right up on you, doesn't it? What am I thinking about?  A forty-one year-old man going out with a girl that's twenty-two, twenty-three?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  Young enough to be your daughter.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, thank you for pointing that out, dad. _Scene Two: KACL radio station. Frasier is doing his show._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_on air_] This is Dr Frasier Crane, KACL 780 talk radio, thanking you for joining us today.  Up next, Bob "Bulldog" Briscoe and the "Gonzo Sports Show."  Until tomorrow, here's wishing you good mental health. [_off air_]

speaker: Bulldog
text: Hey, doc.  Hear the great news?  Ken Griffey Junior's groin pull is completely healed.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank goodness. I'm sure years from now we'll all remember where we were the moment we heard the joyful news.

speaker: Carrie
text: Excuse me, Dr. Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: Hi, Carrie.

speaker: Carrie
text: Hi. I have your pants.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Whoa, doc! [_honks horn_] Where'd you leave them?

speaker: Frasier
text: They're new, Bulldog.  Some of the finer department stores deliver garments to their busier customers.

speaker: Carrie
text: Actually, we don't.  I just thought it would be nice to see you again.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_to Carrie_] Excuse me.  You look very familiar.  Didn't I let you pour a flaming tequila shooter down my throat at Sloppy Nick's during ah, last year's Indy 500?

speaker: Carrie
text: Ah, no.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Well, what are you doing next Memorial Day?

speaker: Frasier
text: Bulldog, as certain as I am that any young lady in the world would love to set your face on fire, Carrie, I believe, is here to see me.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Okay.  Hey, you can't blame a dog for trying. [_going into Roz's booth_] Just on the off chance it might make a difference, I ah, drive a '94 Camaro.

speaker: Carrie
text: Is he gay? [_Frasier looks at her, surprised_] Well, I've been studying about this in school, and it seems like he's really overcompensating.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, I'm not sure. [_smiles_] But I certainly look forward to running that theory by him.  Well um, thank you for the pants, Carrie, and uh, do I owe you anything?

speaker: Carrie
text: Oh, no.  I really enjoyed meeting you yesterday, and it seemed like we had a few laughs together and, maybe we could, you know, go out and have a cup of coffee sometime?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm very flattered that you'd like to go out with me, and uh, jeez, I think you're a beautiful young woman..

speaker: Carrie
text: But?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well it's, it's our ages.  I mean, how old are you?

speaker: Carrie
text: Twenty-two.  How old are you?

speaker: Frasier
text: That's not polite.  I just don't think it would be appropriate for us to date.

speaker: Carrie
text: How about we just live together? [_then_] I'm just trying to lighten an uncomfortable moment.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.  Ha-ha.  Well done.

speaker: Carrie
text: Well, I'm sorry.  But if you change your mind you know where I am.  Enjoy your pants.

speaker: Frasier
text: Same to you.

speaker: Bulldog
text: I only got a second here, but... [_raps on Frasier's forehead, hard_] HELLO?  ANYONE THERE? [_Roz enters_] She wanted to go out with you.  You didn't have to chase her.  You didn't have to harass her.  You didn't have to pay her!  It was like, a miracle.

speaker: Frasier
text: She's too young.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_to Roz_] Are you following any of this?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't expect you to understand.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Great.  'Cause I don't.  So you're not going out with her?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I'm not.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Good.  I'm going to see if I can catch up with her at the elevator.  Maybe she's never dated a former professional hockey player before.

speaker: Frasier
text: You never played hockey.

speaker: Bulldog
text: [_bewildered_] It's like we're from different planets! [_exits_]

speaker: Roz
text: Talk about pathetic.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, isn't he though?

speaker: Roz
text: I meant you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Me?  What, are you saying I should go out with her?

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, take it from me.  It's hard enough to find somebody. So when an opportunity like this comes along, you gotta grab it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, what about the age thing?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, what about it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, come on!  You see an old man walking down the street arm in arm with a beautiful young girl, what do you think?

speaker: Roz
text: I think he must be really rich.  Then I try to make eye contact. **STANLEY BARRISTER MUST BE REALLY,_REALLY_ RICH**  _Scene Three: Cafe Nervosa. Niles joins Frasier._

speaker: Niles
text: There you are, Frasier.  I'm so glad you called me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, thanks for coming, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Some of Maris's friends introduced me to the most delightful party game last night.  I can't wait to share it with you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well Niles, I'd really like to talk...

speaker: Niles
text: No, no.  Shh.  This first, it's a hoot.  If you were stranded on a desert island with one meal, one aria, and one bottle of wine, what would they be?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I really don't...

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, please.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay... A Big Mac, "I'm your Venus," and Ripple.

speaker: Niles
text: ...If you're going to mock the game, then don't play.

speaker: Frasier
text: Gladly.

speaker: Niles
text: Are you still crabbed up about this middle-aged business?

speaker: Frasier
text: No.  No-no-no, I'm fine there.  By the way, you were absolutely right, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Ooh!  I love to hear you say that.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.  But I do have a problem.  You see, the other day I was asked out by a... this twenty-two year old girl that I met in a mall.

speaker: Niles
text: That is alarming.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I turned her down.

speaker: Niles
text: No no, you were in a mall.  Did anyone see you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!  No, I'm just wondering if I made the right decision. You see, I would, I would love to go out with this girl. She's fantastic.  I'm just afraid of looking like some old fool chasing after a young girl.  Becoming a walking mid-life crisis cliche.  Running around like that buffoon Stanley Barrister.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Stanley Barrister.  That is embarrassing, isn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, is that not beyond the pale?  I mean, that girl - how old can she be?

speaker: Niles
text: Twenty-one, if she's a day.

speaker: Frasier
text: I saw them, it was last Tuesday night, together.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, and I saw them together Wednesday morning.

speaker: Both
text: Eww!

speaker: Niles
text: That's disgusting.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's what's so frightening.  Well, this is what I'm afraid of.  People will have the same conversation about me.

speaker: Niles
text: Stanley Barrister is a sixty-year-old man who wears a toupee that looks like something he pulled out of a shower drain. You are forty-one, and obviously not wearing a toupee.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Niles.  So you think it would be okay to go out with this woman?

speaker: Niles
text: Doesn't matter what I think.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it does to me.  You're my brother, I value your opinion.

speaker: Niles
text: My opinion isn't relevant.

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't be coy, Niles.  And will you please stop pursing your lips?  It makes you look like one of those old women they carve out of dried apples.

speaker: Niles
text: [_purses his lips once more, then_] Don't you see?  What I think about you dating a younger woman is immaterial.  What we think about Stanley Barrister is immaterial.  The only thing that matters is what you think.  Ask yourself, if you went out with her, would you be doing it because you were running away from your age, or because you think this has the potential of becoming a meaningful relationship?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know.

speaker: Niles
text: Find out.  And then to hell with what people think.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you are absolutely right.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh!  There it is again, I never tire of hearing that.  Let the tongues of the doubting nabobs wag.  If it feels right, make yourself happy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, thank you. [_gets up_] Oh, by the way Niles, if you were stranded on a desert island, what would you choose as your favorite meal, aria and wine?

speaker: Niles
text: The Coulibiliac of salmon at Guy Savoy, "Vissi d'Arte" from Tosca, and the [_Coutre Roune Ch�teau_] Neuf du Pape '47.

speaker: Frasier
text: You are SO predictable.  _He walks out, leaving Niles gobsmacked.  FADE TO:_  **I WONDER IF THAT ALFA ROMEO SHOWROOM IS STILL OPEN?**  _Scene Four: The Department Store. Carrie is sorting some sweaters when Frasier comes in._

speaker: Frasier
text: Carrie, hi.

speaker: Carrie
text: Hi.  I didn't expect to see you here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well um, I could lie to you and tell you I came here to shop, but actually I came here to see you.

speaker: Carrie
text: That's great.  I've been thinking about you a lot.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I've been thinking a lot about you too, and I just wanted to chat a little bit about why I thought we shouldn't go out.

speaker: Carrie
text: Okay.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you see, I thought I was going through a phase.  You know, well, a mid-life crisis to be frank.  And ah, I was afraid if I went out with you I would be trying to recapture my youth or something.

speaker: Carrie
text: Oh my God.  I can't believe you're saying this.  I was afraid that I asked you out only because I was trying to work out some stuff of my own.  You know, some unresolved issues about my father or something.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh no, no.  Because I went back and forth, you know?  I felt like a fool, and then I didn't...

speaker: Carrie
text: Me, too.  Back and forth.

speaker: Frasier
text: And then I thought maybe you just came along because, to fill some sort of a need or something.

speaker: Carrie
text: Or, or maybe this could be something serious.

speaker: Frasier
text: Exactly.  So... well.  All right, I asked myself a few tough questions..

speaker: Carrie
text: Me too.

speaker: Frasier
text: And well, I finally came to a decision.

speaker: Carrie
text: Me too.  I think us going out would have been really stupid.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_forced enthusiasm_] Me too!

speaker: Carrie
text: It would have completely clouded things with my father, and you and I would never have been on a very firm footing.  But you knew all that.  You could have told me, but you just let me figure it out for myself.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, I'm sort of like the Wizard of Oz.

speaker: Carrie
text: It's no wonder everybody listens to your radio show.  You're so smart.

speaker: Frasier
text: ...Actually, I am full of crap.  I had no idea that you might have been grappling with some personal issues here. Some psychiatrist, huh?  The truth is, I came down here to talk you into going out with me.  I guess it's still a pretty bad idea.

speaker: Carrie
text: You're being so honest with me... that is such an attractive quality in a man. [_she hugs him_]

speaker: Frasier
text: ...Well, you know, let's not go down that road again.

speaker: Carrie
text: Okay.

speaker: Frasier
text: See you around.  _Carrie turns back to her work.  As Frasier leaves, he punches a mannequin with great force.  She looks around at the noise, but he's already gone._
